awd_titl_txt: Multivalent "Artificial Antibody" Based on RNA/Dendrimer-Like Star Polymer Hybrid Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to University of Connecticut by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research is to study the multivalent artificial antibody based on conjugates of RNA aptamers and biodegradable dendrimer-like star polymers, and to prove the concept that these novel nanobiomaterials have properties of antibodies.  Earlier studies have demonstrated that RNA aptamers, which are of smaller size than antibody show minimal immunogenicity, unique binding specificity and affinity, and excellent chemical and biological stability.  The proposal includes design and synthesis of biodegradable dendrimer star-like polymers, conjugation of RNA aptamers to the polymer, and functional characterization of these polymer-RNA conjugates. Antibodies are natural nanomaterials that have been developed over a long-term evolution of life.  Because of their high affinity and specificity to antigens, antibodies have been used in various areas.  Many applications, however, can be significantly hindered because of their immunogenicity, relatively large molecular size, and low chemical and biological stability during manufacturing, shipping, storage and chemical bioconjugation, etc.  The synthetic antibodies that being synthesized are expected to possess superior features such as smaller size than natural antibody, environmentally stable structure, tunable biodegradability, and biocompatible property.  The knowledge developed from these studies would be useful for various technological applications, e.g., targeted drug delivery, diagnosis and biodetection.  

The scientific impact in the development of artificial antibodies would be an enormous breakthrough, and would have huge impacts in the fields of drug delivery, vaccine development and drug targeting among others.  With this award, Professors Wang and Zhu plan to develop a new course in nanobiomaterials and nanomedicine with hands on laboratory for undergraduate students. As part of the outreach program and as part of the Da Vinci program at the University, the investigators will utilize one week training camp for teachers to expose them to the cutting edge of bionanomaterials.  Research results will be broadly disseminated by collaborations with industries through the Associate Programs at the Institute of Materials Science, as well as by publications in quality peer-reviewed journals and presentations at national and international meetings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
During the natural evolution of organisms, various molecular recognition pairs such as antibodies and antigens have been developed. These biomolecular recognition pairs have been extensively studied in a variety of biological and biomedical applications. However, the naturally occurring biomolecules cannot meet many high-level requirements because of their inherent limitations (e.g., easy loss of their functions during the chemical reaction).   Therefore, great efforts have been made for several decades to synthesize biomimetic molecules or systems with novel functionalities. The research objective of this project is to create antibody-like nanostructures by using nucleic acid aptamers and dendritic polymers. The aptamers are used to mimic the binding functions of antibodies whereas the polymers are used to provide a defined site for the loading of therapeutic or diagnostic agents.

            To achieve the goal, we pursued four tasks. First, a new method was successfully developed for the discovery of a small aptamer sequence that was used as the binding sites of the synthetic antibodies. Second, a series of dendrimer-like star polymers (DLSPs) were synthesized. The DLSPs have a hydrophobic core and a hydrophilic shell. These dendritic polymers were systematically characterized with numerous physico-chemical assays. Third, because these polymers hold potential for targeted drug delivery in treating human diseases such as cancer, these dendritic polymers were further studied by the examination of their biodegradation kinetics, drug encapsulation efficiency, and drug delivery efficacy. Fourth, the dendritic polymers including both DLSPs and dendrimers were conjugated with nucleic acid aptamers to develop biomimetic antibodies. A series of cell binding assays were performed to understand the properties of the biomimetic antibodies. It was found that the water solubility of a polymer is an important factor determining the success of the conjugation of aptamers and polymers. Importantly, the results clearly showed that the synthetic antibody made of aptamers and poly(amidoamine) dendrimers could bind to target cancer cells with high strength and specificity similar to natural antibodies. 

            The novel synthetic antibodies hold great potential of being applied to various areas such as cell separation, cancer imaging, and cancer therapy. In addition to these broad scientific impacts, this project has made broader impacts on human resource because of our participation in numerous education and outreach programs. A total of five graduate students and thirteen undergraduate students have been trained to acquire hands-on research experience through this project. The Drug Delivery class has been enriched by the incorporation of nanomedicine synthesis and charcacrerization. This class has been offered to both senior undergraduate students and graduate students each spring semester. In addition, more than twenty K-12 students and teachers have been exposed to the proposed research through the Upward Bound/ConnCAP Program, the E2K Program, the UConn Mentor Connection, the da Vinci Project, and a new program developed based on the collaboration with the E.O. Smith High School. Based on the traning, the participants understand the significance of biomaterials more deeply. A total of nine peer-reviewed journal papers have been published and a new manuscript will be submitted soon. The scientific discovery and the acquired new knowledge have also been broadly disseminated through fi...
por.por_txt_cntn:
During the natural evolution of organisms, various molecular recognition pairs such as antibodies and antigens have been developed. These biomolecular recognition pairs have been extensively studied in a variety of biological and biomedical applications. However, the naturally occurring biomolecules cannot meet many high-level requirements because of their inherent limitations (e.g., easy loss of their functions during the chemical reaction).   Therefore, great efforts have been made for several decades to synthesize biomimetic molecules or systems with novel functionalities. The research objective of this project is to create antibody-like nanostructures by using nucleic acid aptamers and dendritic polymers. The aptamers are used to mimic the binding functions of antibodies whereas the polymers are used to provide a defined site for the loading of therapeutic or diagnostic agents.

            To achieve the goal, we pursued four tasks. First, a new method was successfully developed for the discovery of a small aptamer sequence that was used as the binding sites of the synthetic antibodies. Second, a series of dendrimer-like star polymers (DLSPs) were synthesized. The DLSPs have a hydrophobic core and a hydrophilic shell. These dendritic polymers were systematically characterized with numerous physico-chemical assays. Third, because these polymers hold potential for targeted drug delivery in treating human diseases such as cancer, these dendritic polymers were further studied by the examination of their biodegradation kinetics, drug encapsulation efficiency, and drug delivery efficacy. Fourth, the dendritic polymers including both DLSPs and dendrimers were conjugated with nucleic acid aptamers to develop biomimetic antibodies. A series of cell binding assays were performed to understand the properties of the biomimetic antibodies. It was found that the water solubility of a polymer is an important factor determining the success of the conjugation of aptamers and polymers. Importantly, the results clearly showed that the synthetic antibody made of aptamers and poly(amidoamine) dendrimers could bind to target cancer cells with high strength and specificity similar to natural antibodies. 

            The novel synthetic antibodies hold great potential of being applied to various areas such as cell separation, cancer imaging, and cancer therapy. In addition to these broad scientific impacts, this project has made broader impacts on human resource because of our participation in numerous education and outreach programs. A total of five graduate students and thirteen undergraduate students have been trained to acquire hands-on research experience through this project. The Drug Delivery class has been enriched by the incorporation of nanomedicine synthesis and charcacrerization. This class has been offered to both senior undergraduate students and graduate students each spring semester. In addition, more than twenty K-12 students and teachers have been exposed to the proposed research through the Upward Bound/ConnCAP Program, the E2K Program, the UConn Mentor Connection, the da Vinci Project, and a new program developed based on the collaboration with the E.O. Smith High School. Based on the traning, the participants understand the significance of biomaterials more deeply. A total of nine peer-reviewed journal papers have been published and a new manuscript will be submitted soon. The scientific discovery and the acquired new knowledge have also been broadly disseminated through fifteen conference presentations.

					Submitted by: Yong Wang
